Contracted employment provision is where private, public and voluntary sector providers give to those who need help in finding and keeping work assistance. Provision performance and Controls Division provides the infrastruture that supports contracted employment provision, including systems for referral, payment, financial assurance, compliance, security, performance monitoring and analysis and the Merlin Standard.

The team supports the delivery of Housing Benefit and Council Tax Benefit, allocating and managing the DWP funding to local authorities. We analyse performance data and support local authorities in improving their delivery. We support local authority housing costs teams in preparing for the changes that Universal Credit and welfare reform will bring.
Developing DWP Commissioning Strategy and working with Strategy Group on changes to current and future Work Programmes

column5: Head of Tell Us Once Delivery Partnerships
column6: Delivering the Tell Us Once service enabling citizens to notify government once of a birth or a death.
Developing a quality & assurance framework across DWP operations
Managing all contracted employment programmes delivered by third party providers on behalf of the Department.

column5: Head of Provision Performance & Controls Division
column6: The Provision Performance & Controls Division exists to improve provider performance and to set our future strategy for contracting, as well as providing support to existing provision. The Division is responsible for:- (1) The implementation of DWP’s commissioning and market strategy for contracted employment provision including localisation; (2) The performance and financial allocations for third party provision; (3) The monitoring and performance improvement of contracted employment provision including inspection and other assurance and (4) Analytical work across the commissioning and delivery cycle.

Accountable for leading a multi-channel customer service delivery organisation comprising £7K staff with responsibility for the timely and accurate delivery of £87b of public expenditure to £14m customers across the UK and abroad, specifically State Pension, Pension Credit, Winter Fuel Payments and Carers Allowance.

Provision of technical learning to DWP frontline staff, responsible for development and maintenance of guidance, products, in-house small systems, release scoping, MI gateway, advice and impacting new strategy initiatives.

column5: Director General, DWP Operations and SRO for the Child Maintenance Change Programme
column6: Responsible for the development and provision of DWP's services to the public, including those provided by partners or under contract. Also Senior Responsible Owner for the Child Maintenance Change Programme.
Responsible for leading the DWP team supporting the Secretary of State for Work and Pensions in respect of his cross-Government responsibilities for social justice and child poverty.

Responsible for leading on the overall DWP strategy for the labour market for now and under Universal Credit; the labour market regimes for working age claimants; and DWP work across government and with external partners to achieve better outcomes for young people and working age claimants.

Responsible for developing a regime that supports increased pension saving and minimises the burden on employers. Responsibility for delivering a major reform  starting in October 2012 when on a staged basis all employers, starting with the largest, will be required to automatically enrol their work force into a pension. Unless the employee chooses to opt out employer and employee will be required to make a minimum contribution to the pension. The team are overseeing the development of a new low cost pension – National Employment Savings Trust. The team is also responsible, with the Pensions Regulator and the Pension Protection Fund for ensuring an effective regime for pension protection.

The team owns the overall strategic vision for the DWP and connects people working on strategy with operations by making sure that the strategy developed is deliverable and that what the strategy says is done.

Advises and supports Ministers and the Executive Team in the formulation and deliverability of policy relating to the Government’s welfare, work and pension reforms as well as the social justice agenda, including looking beyond the individual reforms already underway.

The Directorate is responsible for State Pensions policy and legislation, supporting Ministers in their overall reform of the State Pensions system and developing and modelling options for reform of the State Pensions system in support of Ministerial objectives of equality and fairness and Older People & the Ageing Society Strategy Division.

My team leads the development and maintenance of policy for most of the main benefits for people of working age, including Universal Credit, Jobseeker's Allowance, Employment and Support Allowance and Housing Benefit.

column5: Head of Business Strategy & Change Assessment
column6: The Division’s purpose is to: set the strategic direction for the delivery of the Department’s business. For example, for the use of digital channels and telephony; taking responsibility for the Departmental policy on Identity and National Insurance Number policy; and ensuring that all policy and business changes are properly considered to ensure they are both affordable and deliverable.
Head of Universal Credit Business Transformation Strand.

column5: Director Disability Directorate and Office for Disability Issues
column6: Policy advice to Ministers on issues relating to disablity, employment, benefits and rights.

Responsibility for Employment and Support Allowance/ Incapacity Benefit Programme and Strategic Design Authority. This includes: the proposed contribution-based Employment and Support Allowance legislative changes 2012, Work Capability Assessment Harrington Review Implementation and the reassessment of Incapacity Benefits claimants. The role is specifically to ensure delivery of these policies and/or business intent within the appropriate timescales, to budget and in support of operational delivery. Also leading on the design and maintenance of the overarching DWP business architecture to ensure the Department is equipped to deliver its vision. This involves supporting programmes and projects in their understanding and ensuring designs are integrated, aligned and support strategic intent.

Expert domain for the analysis and interpretation of regional, national and international labour market trends, including the monthly labour market National Statistics, the department’s overall approach to employment policy and cross government working on labour market issues.

The team is responsible for deciding how European Social Fund money should be spent in England and Gibraltar and for managing the expenditure by supporting and checking providers and submitting claims to the European Commission.

column5: Deputy Director, Labour Market Partnerships Division
column6: Labour Market Partnerships Division leads on defining and shaping strategic partnerships to meet the needs of employers and localities and develop the skills of workless people to help more people back into employment. It does this by encouraging and facilitating the coherent delivery of services between DWP and other partners, whether they be in the public, private or voluntary and community sectors.

Tasked with co-ordinating DWP activity on mental health and employment, including close working with Health and Wellbeing Directorate and where appropriate other government departments. There are two significant strands to this work. The first is to lead on the mental health aspect of the disability employment strategy, and the second is to manage the Mental Health and Employment Strategy Board. Part of this work involves setting out future options for this agenda, which have been informed by wide ranging discussions across government and the voluntary and community sector, and include experts by experience.

column5: Deputy Director, Disability and Work Opportunities
column6: Responsible for the Disability Employment Strategy, policy on the Department’s specialist disability employment programmes, and sponsorship of Remploy.

column5: Lead Analyst, Universal Credits and Working Age
column6: Providing the evidence and analysis to support the development of policy and delivery for Universal Credit, Housing Benefits and Working Age Benefits.

column5: Deputy Director, Work, Welfare & Wellbeing in Later Life
column6: Strategy on: up-rating of social security benefits and State pensions; employment, welfare benefits and wellbeing for older people; extending working life; combatting pensioner poverty and material deprivation among older people; and engagement with older people. Maintenance and reform of Pension Credit. Maintenance of universal pensioner benefits. Income aspects of combatting fuel poverty, including operation of the Warm Home Discount Scheme.

column5: Head of Business Strategy & Change Assessment
column6: The Division’s purpose is to: set the strategic direction for the delivery of the Department’s business. For example, for the use of digital channels and telephony; taking responsibility for the Departmental policy on Identity and National Insurance Number policy; and ensuring that all policy and business changes are properly considered to ensure they are both affordable and deliverable.

Operate an effective stewardship framework around our pensions sponsored bodies, The Pensions Regulator, Pension Protection Fund, The Pensions Advisory Service and The Pensions Ombudsman, ensure bodies deliver their objectives and operate efficiently and effectively within their legal frameworks and current financial constraints. Ensure that regulation of work-based pensions increases member and employer confidence in the security of benefits and quality of pension scheme administration while considering the burden on sponsoring employers and effects on wider economy. Ensure that the Financial Assistance Scheme and the Pension Protection Fund provide effective compensation or assistance to members of pension schemes which wind up under-funded.

column5: Head of Private Pensions Policy & Analysis
column6: Responsible for the policy, legislation and regulation that underpins the private pension system in the UK.
Responsible for providing policy advice to Ministers on Housing Benefit, Council Tax Benefit and Support for Mortgage Interest, and the housing element of Universal Credit and Pension Credit.
Responsible for policy for contributory pensions including reform and state pension age.

column5: Deputy Director Office for Disability Issues
column6: The Office for Disability Issues aims to make a real difference to the quality of life of disabled people.  We: support the Minister for Disabled People in her cross-Government role to enable disabled people to fulfil their potential; lead on development, communication and delivery of the Government’s disability strategy, working across government and with disabled people and their organisations; and promote and defend UK disability policies internationally including in the UN and EU.

column5: Deputy Director, Lead Analyst for Pensions and Ageing
column6: Accountable for the evidence base on which Ministers will make decisions on state pensions, private pensions regulation, supporting people to work in to later life and the challenges of an ageing society. In addition work on pensioner poverty measurement and options to alleviate are also carried out in this area as well as evaluation of autoenrollment whereby everyone in work has access to an occupational pension.

DWP Insight develops and leverages our comprehensive understanding of the needs and behaviours of our service users (claimants, customers, staff, empoyers, intermediaries) in order to ensure the Department: - drives behaviour change to achieve the stated policy and service outcomes and creates more effective policies and services minimising cost to the Department, its users and the taxpayer.

Lead DWP strategy on EU and international business. This includes departmental interests in the EU and broader international agenda and work with organisations such as the International Labour Organisation, OECD, Council of Europe, G20 and key countries.

column5: Head of Working Age Benefits Division
column6: Responsible for the design, development, monitoring & evaluation of policies on (& the associated evidence base for) Employment & Support Allowance, Jobseekers Allowance, Maternity Allowance, Statutory Sick Pay & Statutory Maternity Pay, Incapacity Benefit Reassessment, Industrial Injuries Disablement Benefit, Carers Allowance, Income Support & Severe Disablement Allowance. Also, analysis, evidence & evaluation of the operational delivery of all working age benefits, including their interaction with Housing Benefit, pensions/pension credit & Universal Credit. Lead on structural and cross cutting benefit issues such as means testing and passporting.

column5: Director Universal Credit Policy and Service
column6: The Universal Credit Product and Service Design team is responsible for defining the service to be provided to claimants and staff for Universal Credit and translates the policy intention into a design specification.

Leading preparation of the content for major Ministerial conference on employing disabled people, including developing policy for announcements on the day, identification of, and liaison with, speakers, speeches and briefing for all Ministerial speeches and stakeholder liaison.

This post is responsible for the co-ordination, delivery and quality assurance of all analysis across DWP. Analytical teams: (a) contribute to the process of evidence based policy development and delivery design; (b) help to monitor and evaluate the impacts of Departmental policies; (c) provide analytical information to support the Parliamentary and legislative process; (d)  provide forecasts of benefit expenditure to support HMT's sound planning of the Government finances.

Responsible for forecasting expenditure on all state benefits and pensions within DWP’s remit, and in most cases the equivalents for Northern Ireland. This is undertaken for the Office for Budget Responsibility and HM Treasury as well as DWP itself. Also responsible for forecasting business volumes (e.g. claims, changes of circumstance, numbers passing particular qualification thresholds for labour market programmes) for all of DWP, and the associated appeals for the Tribunals Service. And provision of information on benefit expenditure to Parliament and other organisations and individuals.

Measurement of fraud and error in the benefits system (under and over-payments) and publication of related National Statistics; Compilation of National and other official statistics relating to benefits and claimants and related analyses in support of policy development; Measurement of incomes and poverty, including child, working-age and pensioner poverty and income inequality through the Family Resources Survey; Departmental lead for the Wealth and Assets Survey, the English Longitudinal Study of Ageing, the Life Opportunities Survey, and related analyses. Deputy Head of Profession for statistics: upholding professional standards including the Code of Practice for Official Statistics.
Provides analytical support that cuts across policy areas to Ministers and others. Manages research and the deployment of analysts across the Department.

Responsible for medical and health related advice to Ministers and the Department; for quality of all medical related work including oversight of quality of work of medical services contractor; for medical and health related policy within the Department;  for leading the health, work and wellbeing agenda on behalf of the Department; for oversight of all science based research as Departmental Chief Scientific Adviser; and for external relationships with healthcare professional bodies and other key stakeholders.

column5: Deputy Director for Disability Assessment and Deputy Chief Medical Adviser

This includes overall responsibility for development and maintenance of policy in relation to the health aspects of benefit entitlement assessments; for the overview of professional standards in relation to the provision of contracted-out medical services; and for technical support to the Industrial Injuries Advisory Council.

The team is accountable for the delivery and management of DWP services across a virtual, multi-channel network comprising telephone and digital services. They are responsible for ensuring that these services are delivered efficiently and coherently to required customer service standards, ensuring that business targets and objectives are met and constantly measured for sustained performance improvement. The team also has responsibility for driving the transformation of DWP business from a face to face and telephony business to one where online channels become the contact method of choice for customers and claimants, where appropriate.

column5: Head of Digital & Online Services for DWP Operations
column6: Responsible for the live running of Digital Services within DWP Operations, and delivering activities that will transform DWP from a telephony and face to face business to one where online channels become the contact method of choice for our customers, where appropriate. We achieve this by driving the continuous improvement of the services and ensuring that customers and claimants are aware of the digital services we provide.

Accountable for delivery of all performance targets balanced with the needs of customers and Treasury efficiency measures. Contribute to the Department’s significant efficiency challenge through management of estates, resource, process and technology change and optimisation.  Develop & deliver operational & change implementation plans, based in a digital environment, moving the organisation to a multi channel service.  Identify and mitigate operational risks.  Understand & communicate telephony, digital & contact centre end to end system & the enablers to deliver a quality customer experience & value for money.  Understand technology development & understand how other similar organisations & outsourcers are improving multi-channel customer facing services.  Develop & promote business cases, at Ministerial level, for strategic change pilots & projects via Operational Excellence Team.  Develop & drive the right key performance indicators to improve the customer experience & facilitate the required channel switch.

Delivery of IT infrastructure & security capabilities is support of Universal Credit

Service Design ensures that computer system designs are operationally sound, that systems have the required capacity and that all necessary Personal Computer services are provided.

column6: The projects cover all business areas including internal financial systems, infrastructure upgrades, labour market initiatives such as Universal Jobmatch, Benefit Cap and recently the Work Programme. IT Director accountable and responsible for the creation design & delivery of the Legacy (IT) Replacement Programme to remove the department’s dependency on legacy IT

Responsible for the delivery of all working age benefits including Jobseekers Allowance, Employment Support Allowance, Income Support, Disability Living Allowance and Personal Independence Payment. Accountable for the accurate payment of c.£30 billion of expenditure and the leadership of 22,000 staff across 72 sites. Senior Responsible Owner for Personal Independence Payment, Appeals Reform and Spend to Save.

column5: Head of Disability, Delivery and Benefits
column6: Currently responsible for all Disability operations, for example, benefits such as Disability Living Allowance and Attendance Allowance.

The objective of the team is to be the best value provider of Finance and HR services for its clients and the taxpayer.  To support this objective it is helping the Efficiency Reward Group to provide a cross-government strategy to all government departments on the potential of utilising Shared Services.

Accountable for the successful day to day delivery of Financial Services and Employee Services for four Government Departments. Responsible for monitoring and accounting for the Departmental Expenditure Limit expenditure for clients totalling in excess of £10 billion and Annually Managed Expenditure £150bn. Responsible for management of staff to accurately pay £4 billion to government suppliers. Also responsible for the successful management of payroll and first line HR advice for over 100,000 government employees.

column5: Head of Service Optimisation and Efficiency
column6: The team is responsible for developing and delivering an efficiency plan and new Target Operating model for DWP Shared Services, in order to delivery annual operating efficiencies of 10%, and to position Shared Services to respond positively to the Cabinet Office, Efficiency Reform Group, Shared Services strategy for Government. The efficiency programme will use industry benchmarks and best practice to refine processes and remove duplication of work. We are also working on the development and introduction of improved IT where it is appropriate to do so, and an estates strategy to maximise the estate footprint and reduce overheads.

Responsible for managing the safe delivery and implementation of all major change activity into Shared Services. These changes include modifications and upgrades to our computer systems, ensuring that all the related business process changes have been identified, are comprehensively planned and implemented without adversely affecting the delivery of the Shared Services business. They also include managing the take-on of new Crown organisations where they select DWP Shared Services as their service provider.

Corporate Services is responsible for providing financial, HR and facilities management services supporting the Shared Services Organisation. Provision of advice on all Human Resources matters, including organisational development, recruitment and selection, performance management and disciplinary and grievance procedures. To manage the Organisation’s Governance and Risk Management to ensure compliance within departmental control and audit requirements.  To provide and manage a range of facilities management services including Estates, Security, Business Continuity, Communications and Freedom of Information.

column5: Director General for the Universal Credit Programme
column6: The Universal Credit Director General and Senior Responsible Owner is accountable for implementing the government’s main welfare reform programme. This includes (1) owning and communicating the vision of the programme; (2) ensuring the implementation of Universal Credit is completed safely and securely and (3) providing clear leadership to the programme team

Responsible for ensuring that robust, transparent and deliverable programme plans are in place and that programme momentum is maintained.   Also responsible for ensuring that joint and collective accountabilities are clear, that commissioning arrangements are appropriately specified and that the right level of timely direction is given across the whole programme.

The team is responsible for the design, development and delivery of a number of major change projects and programmes for which the Finance Director General, DWP acts as the overall Senior Responsible Officer. These change initiatives cover the development and enhancement of systems and processes supporting internal functions, such as the Department's Resource Management System, as well as customer facing ones, such as those delivering enhanced customer payment and debt services.

column5: Programme Director, Personal Independence Payment / Employment and Support Allowance, and Incapacity Benefit Reassessment
column6: The Programme Director is accountable for successful delivery of the day to day running of the programme and delivery of the programme objectives to timescales outlined including the monitoring and reporting of expenditures and costs against delivered and realised benefits as the programme progresses for: the Personal Independence Payment, a new benefit, from 2013/14 replacing Disability Living Allowance for eligible working age claimants (aged 16 to 64); Contribution-based Employment and Support Allowance legislative changes 2012; Work Capability Assessment, Harrington Review Implementation and the reassessment of Incapacity Benefits (Income Support) claimants.

Responsible for, Internal and external partner and stakeholder management including: Other Government Departments, Devolved administrations, 
Local Authorities, Ministers and Lobby Groups. Briefing and support for, Parliamentary correspondence, Freedom of Information etc Internal and external communications.

The Programme Director is responsible, and held acount by the SRO, for the successful delivery of the day to day running of the Programme, delivery of the Programme objectives, monitoring benefits realised against the Business case.The Programme Director is also responsible for the overall integrity and coherence of the Programme, providing leadership, direct line management of project strand leads, chair governance boards/meetings and engagement with key internal and external delivery partners and stakeholders.

The post-holder will be accountable for ensuring that the design of the products and services within Universal Credit deliver the required experience for customers and the required changes in their attitudes and behaviours.

column5: Director of DWP Portfolio Management Unit
column6: Portfolio Management Unit plays a key role in managing the end-to-end change process & provides independent assurance to the DWP Executive Team (ET) through the Portfolio Board (PB) & the Portfolio Management Committee (PMC) whilst enabling the successful delivery of the department’s change portfolio. Responsible for delivery of a programme of projects that impact on Benefits Delivery, including Appeals Reform.

Responsible for introducing a service to allow citizens to inform Government once that there has been a birth or bereavement. To develop a programme of work to transform how we tackle Fraud and Error in benefits and credits.
To develop the implementation strategy, detailed implementation approach and supporting implementation plans for Universal Credit

column5: Head of Universal Credit, Business Process
column6: To develop the business processes and business products that are required to support Universal Credit delivery.

Responsible for the delivery of a programme of change projects covering State Pensions, Pension Credit and all other changes relating to the delivery and payment of State Pensions and related benefits to Pension Age customers.

column5: Head of Process Excellence Universal Credit

To have a process in place across the 3 strands that maintains the intent and integrity of the policy through to physical operation of UC. Ensuring that products meet the exit and entry criteria in terms of quality and completeness from one strand to another.
To programme manage the Personal Independence Payment Implementation programme.

Sitting within the Universal Credit Programme, but responsible for ensuring the end-to-end security delivery capability is in place to provide secure online and other services for both Universal Credit and the wider Department.

Universal Credit Pathfinder Delivery Director. As part of that delivery, develop and implement Pathfinder live operational processes, and jointly lead and manage the Pathfinder UC service with DWP operational colleagues, ensuring the service is available and operates effectively, managing and capturing issues as they arise. As Pathfinder is designed to allow Universal Credit to learn from operational experience, ensure formal evaluation and lessons learned are captured in order to inform the future Universal Credit service.
To drive financial efficiencies through the introduction of Smarter Working and the divestment of Estate.

column5: Programme Director Specialist Disability Employment Programme
column6: I manage a programme team of 45 people and investment budget of £120m. The Programme will finish in July 2014.
Responsible for providing advice and assistance on the use of RTI within DWP and for ensuring that the necessary DWP requirements are fed into the HMRC processes for delivering RTI.
To deliver changes to ensure that as many people as possible are in work.
Project manager with overall responsibility for the successful implementation of the Benefit Cap project in 2013.

column5: Head of Labour Market Intervention Strategy
column6: To develop and evaluate labour market interventions which will move people on DWP benefits into work or more or better paid work; and to provide advice to Ministers and others on these issues.

To deliver DWP's programme of Business Change that will be enabled by digitally based projects to help the Department achieve its goal of “Digital by Default”.

column5: Head of Operational Planning and Delivery

Supports field operations in identifying and managing risk, disruption and preserving continuity of operations. Staff in this division cover roles including: change sponsorship, change implementation, network and staff capacity planning, estates rationalisation and support; Parliamentary correspondence; customer complaints; briefing for senior officials and Ministers; FOI request responses and the model office.

Fraud Investigation Service investigates potential fraudulent attacks against all benefits owned by DWP or administered on behalf of DWP. It works in partnership with Local Authorities, other Government Departments, including HMRC, the Police and other relevant bodies. It also conducts financial investigations, referred by a criminal investigator or in accordance with directives from the courts with a view to recovering money illegally obtained through criminal activity.

To co-ordinate the programme of Transformation Board agreed pilots, to ensure that successful pilots move into Trailblazers & National Rollout, giving due consideration to capacity/impact within operations and change division to implement successfully.  To oversee HASSRA take-up/percentage of DWP Headcount & ensure delivery of Community 10,000 measures

column5: Head of Service Design and Development
column6: The Head of Service Design and Management is responsible for managing all ‘live’ products and services delivered by DWP Operations. The post holder must ensure that operational outcomes are delivered for customers within the stated Policy intent and budgetary constraints.  The job holder provides the interface into Strategy and Policy for each of the live services and also works with Change teams where new products or services are being developed to ensure effective operational input.

Operational Excellence has 2 primary roles: accountability for the service integrity of the benefit system (fraud and error and security) and for driving up operational excellence across the whole of operations. The Directorate is split into 4 areas: Fraud & Error Service, Central Operations, Service Design & Management and Change & Implementation.

column5: Work Services Director, North East England
column6: To deliver services to enable and support unemployed claimants to access employment opportunties in the North East England through 105 Jobcentre outlets.

Responsible for the delivery of face-to-face services through Jobcentres, partnerships, and the visiting service. Personally accountable as: Senior Responsible Owner (SRO) for the Labour Market change programme and Earned Autonomy, which is delivering greater flexibility for Jobcentre Plus Districts;  Senior User Executive for the Universal Credit Programme, helping to ensure the voice of Operations is properly represented and that proposals are deliverable.

column5: Work Services Director, Wales and Employers

They drive performance improvement across the Jobcentre network, and provide senior leadership across the Group; delivering and championing key government initiatives to help get Britain back to work. They are also responsible for national engagement with employers.

To provide appropriate HR interventions to enable the delivery of the department's major change programmes, to manage the people impacts of change and the delivery of the people plan. Also to provide HR Business partner services to the Change functions and programmes.

column5: Director General, Human Resources & Head of Government HR Operations
column6: Responsible for delivering an HR service to the Department’s 100,000 employees and management. To ensure that this HR service is cost-effective and supports the customer-focused delivery of the Department’s activities.

column5: HR Director, Civil Service Employee Policy

Working closely with government departments, we deliver simplified, rationalised policies, including guidance and support with implementation.  We also offer an Expert Advice Service to deliver the priorities of the strategic centre (Cabinet Office, HM Treasury, Treasury Solicitors) and departments.

column5: Director of HR Strategy & Organisation Development
column6: Lead the development & delivery of the DWP People Strategy & operating model for HR.  Provide strategic & functional leadership to the Corporate HR Business Partners, including driving through organisational changes & providing the ‘voice’ of the Corporate Centre to the HR Executive team.  Provide strategic HR support to change activities across the Department through the Change Programme and other major programmes of change within the Department.  Provide effective & efficient processes for prioritising the work of the HR Function and the allocation of HR resources to key Departmental priorities.  Lead the work on defining, agreeing and monitoring the performance framework for HR ensuring that the outcomes delivered by HR support business performance.  Act as the Finance Director and Business support office for Corporate HR.

HR Business Partner to the Chief Operating Officer of DWP Operations. Providing strategic advice to the DWP Operations executive team. Leading Business Partner teams based throughout the country which support senior managers in DWP Operations to continue to deliver the Department's services efficiently to the public. Also working cross-Whitehall to ensure the HR community plays an effective part in driving forward standards and professionalism throughout the HR community and wider Civil Service.

column5: Head of Diversity & Equality Civil Service
column6: The purpose of the role is to develop and implement the Department for Work & Pensions diversity and equality strategy, enabling the Department to meet its objectives, specifically to comply with equality legislation and to become an exemplary service provider and employer. The team also leads on the development of the Civil Service diversity strategy for the workforce and delivery of the Government’s Social Mobility Internship Scheme.

HR Director providing strategic Business Partner support to the Universal Credit Director General & the Programme.The HR function provides both a HRBP service to the Programme, ensuring the programme is the right size with the right capabilities & “fit” to deliver its plan. In addition the team will form part of the Business Transformation by leading on diagnosing, designing & delivering the organisation & people elements of change driven by Universal Credit.

Responsible for (1) the development & delivery of HR Policy including Pay & Reward strategy; (2) the provision of services on HR performance & resource planning, business & HR management intelligence; (3) the management of a range of departmental health/ wellbeing contracts covering 17 Govt Departments; (4) the leadership of Complex Case Advisory Service & the leadership of HR Mediation/ Investigation Service; (5) the lead on Employee Relations and Health & Safety; (6) to ensure effective & efficient provision of services provided by Shared Services in DWP & X-government & compliance to Departmental governance & assurance requirements; & (7) to oversee the strategic direction & delivery of the DWP & cross-Civil Service Diversity & Equality agenda.
Leads on strategic workforce planning for the Department and co-ordinates delivery of workforce requirements such as exit schemes, redeployment and recruitment.

column5: Head of HR Professionalism and Talent
column6: Responsible for talent management, development and professionalism of the cross Government HR community.

Responsible for leading a small team of strategic Organisation Development and Design consultants the job-holder provides direct consulting input and support to programmes as part of the DWP Change Portfolio; as well as contributing to the development of business strategy, the departmental blueprint and operating model; and leading on the design and delivery of direct and commissioned interventions to develop leadership and improve employee engagement.

Responsible for providing strategic HR advice and support to the Strategy Group in addressing business requirements.  Implementing strategies to deliver the right people in the right place at the right time with the right skills and to increase organisational performance and effectiveness.

column5: Director General, Finance and Chief Financial Officer
column6: Responsible for financial planning, performance management, procurement, estates provision, investment portfolio and risk assurance across the Department. Responsible for the financial control environment for benefit payments totalling over £150 billion and for the departmental financial management processes controlling a Departmental Expenditure limit of £7.8 billion. Holds direct budgetary responsibility for an operating and capital budget of £600m.

A dual role that is both accountable for all DWP commercial activity, covering business worth around £4.6 billion in 2010/11, and also Deputy Chief Procurement Officer for all Government procurement. As DWP Commercial Director, managing a specialist procurement organisation and leading DWP commercial, sustainability and travel strategies and the commercial management of contracts covering the delivery of services to DWP. As Deputy Chief Procurement Officer, contributing to transforming Government procurement and leading Crown negotiations with major suppliers. Key objectives are to improve public sector procurement capability and so reduce expenditure, contribute to reducing the budget deficit and promote economic growth.

column5: Director, Departmental Planning and Performance Management
column6: Leads negotiations with HM Treasury on Departmental funding; advises Ministers and the Executive team on the allocation and management of resources across the Department; reports internally and externally on the Department’s performance; and provides financial, planning and performance management support to the Department’s Strategy function.

Financial Control is at the heart of Finance and Commercial’s integrated operating model, providing regular financial and performance reports to business partners enabling them to support the business to manage resources effectively, control costs and drive performance. The Directorate produces the Department's Resource Accounts and undertakes a broad range of other activities including provision of: advice on risk and control; banking services and resolution of payment issues, and debt control. Financial Control also maintain the financial systems strategy, helping to ensure key financial systems and processes are effectively controlled.

column5: Head of Commercial Management - Business Services

Contracts include those for the provision of the Department’s logistics, post, banking and encashment, medical assessment services and shared services. Key objectives are to meet the DWP, and through collaboration wider Government, requirements for goods and services by managing commercial arrangements under public sector procurement policies to achieve best value for money for the taxpayer.

Debt Management is responsible for collecting Debt and Compensation on behalf of DWP, Local Authorities, other Government Departments and the NHS. It also administers the Integrated Loan Scheme on behalf of the Home Office. 1800 staff are primarily housed in 9 locations and forms part of DWP Finance and Commercial Directorate.

To raise the profile of Finance and work closely with key stakeholders to build strong relationships and have an excellent understanding of their dedicated business area. To support the IT Executive Team in delivering 'Better for Less' ensuring robust and secure IT is in place to the satisfaction of our colleagues and the citizens we serve while reducing the cost of providing that service. Keeping the business safe, in terms of its financial & commercial controls/mechanisms, finance policy and delegated financial authority. Supporting the value for money agenda and delivering options and solutions proactively within our overall SR10 funding envelope and targets to deliver the SR13 settlement for DWP

BI is a single, integrated finance function to provide high quality financial, performance and productivity information throughout the Department and for external reporting.  BI undertake all routine Financial and Performance reporting (data gathering and production) at the business unit and DWP level, providing ‘one version of the truth’ for the Departments' financial and non-financial information, eliminating duplication and ensuring sign off from the respective business owners.  BI conduct initial Level 1 challenge and analysis and ensure that the messages and datasets are consistent, accurate and complete.

column5: Business Partner, Pensions and Operational Excellence

column5: Head of Division for DWP Performance, Reporting & Planning
column6: The performance reporting & planning division is responsible for internal reporting of departmental performance (to DWP senior leaders and the DWP board) and external reporting to Cabinet Office, Parliament and oversight of the department's relationship with the National Audit Office. We also lead departmental business planning and continual review of the allocation of departmental resources against Ministerial priorities.

column5: Head of Commercial Management (Information and Communication Technology)
column6: Part of Commercial Directorate (Group Finance) and responsible for commercial management of all third party spend on Information and Communication Technology with suppliers across the department. The team works very closely with Corporate IT and also external supply chain in driving value for money on various contracts/statements of work/orders drawn under pre-existing commercial frameworks. The team is also involved in influencing commercial strategy and (on select occasions) procurement decisions for the department.

Responsible for managing professional teams that provide commercial management of a range of major office service contracts and supplier relationships that deliver goods and services to the DWP, business worth about £1.1 Billion in 2010/11. Contracts include those for the provision of the Department’s estate, voice and data networks, travel and professional services. Key objectives are to meet the DWP, and some wider Government, requirements for these goods and services by managing commercial arrangements under public sector procurement policies to achieve the best value for money for the taxpayer.

A key element of the role is to develop an agreed contracting approach for each Sourcing activity resulting in all tenders having an agreed approach at commencement. This involves understanding DWP requirements, market preparation, OJEU/PQQ development, evaluation, award, de-briefing bidders and Regulatory post award activity.

Providing advice support and challenge to business leaders in the area of risk management and internal control and reporting levels of compliance with key internal policies to provide assurance that the system of internal control is effective.

To provide professional, evidence based, decision making support, challenge and professional advice to the Directorate on all aspects of financial management, performance and risk. This is achieved by leading and coordinating on a range of business disciplines – Financial Management and Control, Performance Management, risk management and oversight of assurance and Governance.

column5: Head of Universal Credit Commercial Management
column6: Accountable for planning and implementing the commercial arrangements necessary for the successful implementation of Universal Credit.  Lead a team to develop and implement the right commercial strategy in line with EU and public sector procurement policies to deliver efficient procurements that meet the requirements of the Universal Credit project and achieve the best value for money for the taxpayer.  This will include procurement of Information and Communication Technology and other services and managing the impact on other commercial arrangements within and outside DWP.

column5: Head of Finance Systems and Infrastructure
column6: Our core aim is to protect and manage the Department's payment processes. We have ownership of Payment processes, including Central Payment System (processing £140b annually). Engagement with Change Programmes, ensuring incorporation of Finance requirements. We protect claimants by supporting resolution of payment issues. Includes bank payments and transfers; third party deductions and control of payment files. We act as the Single Point Of Contact (SPOC) to Shared Services in coordinating and prioritising change. Also handles Information Asset Co-ordination for Finance.

column5: Head of Commercial Strategy and Business Management
column6: Responsible for DWP commercial strategy and the business management of the DWP Commercial Directorate.  Leadership of teams providing commercial strategy, policy, best practice and e-solutions covering all DWP commercial activity, sustainability and climate change strategies. Also management of teams that plan and manage the DWP Commercial Directorate, including work prioritisation, resource management and people development. Key objectives are reducing procurement costs, lean processes, maximising commercial assurance and value for money for the taxpayer and achievement of DWP sustainability, climate change and carbon reduction targets.

column5: Head of Universal Credit & Automated Service Delivery
column6: To provide professional accountancy support to programme managers, delivering key welfare reform projects so that investment costs represent value for money, are affordable and projected spend is controlled ensuring delivery to time, budget and quality.

Delivery of a professional Internal Audit service to provide an independent view on the adequacy and effectiveness of the Department’s governance, risk and control arrangements. Establishment of the European Social Fund Audit Authority for the England and Gibraltar programme, in accordance with EC requirements. Provision of independent and robust investigation of serious fraud and wrongdoing by the Department’s staff and contractors.

column5: Head of Working Age Change Finance
column6: To provide professional accountancy support to Programme Managers delivering key Welfare Reform projects so that: investment costs represent value for money, are affordable and project spend is controlled, ensuring delivery to time, budget and quality.

Ensuring the effective management of resources, risks to the delivery of business objectives and compliance with all DWP’s financial policies.
Management of all commercial aspects of the Department's tird party expenditure on Information Technology & Communication technologies

Support the Finance Director Corporate and Change in delivering an effective Business Decision Support function for DWP’s policy and corporate, (excluding IT), business areas.

column5: Director of Information, Governance and Security

The Directorate provides a range of services to support this, including the production of statistics; management information; information architecture; analytical data bases; data matching; records management; and library services . It also provides the department with expert advice on security;  business continuity; policies on information; its governance framework; and managing relationships with its arms length bodies and the devolved administrations.

column5: Head of Information to Support Delivery
column6: Maximise, securely the use of information and data to support the operational delivery of Departmental functions and wider government activities.

column5: Deputy Director, Statistical Services Division and Deputy Head of Profession for Statistics
column6: Responsible for the production and dissemination of a range of National Statistics eg Benefit and Welfare to Work Programme stats and Fraud and Error in the benefits system and exploitation of DWP data in the development of statistical reports. To provide advice in relation to the production and publication of Official Statistics and data for responses to Parliamentary Questions. To be responsible for the design and delivery of a range of surveys and subsequent publication of survey reports.

column5: Head of Information Management, Devolution and Governance Division
column6: Information Management, Devolution and Governance Division enables the DWP to use the information it is responsible for effectively and lawfully. When it is appropriate the Division facilitates the release of information into the public domain. Its centres of expertise also ensure the Department’s stewardship teams exercise appropriate oversight over DWP's Non–Departmental Public Bodies and support DWP in developing successful relationships with the UK’s devolved governments in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. Additionally the Division's governance policies and assurance controls ensure Departmental accountabilities are defined, assurance controls are thorough and challenged, following best practice and mandatory policy.

column5: Deputy Director Security and Business Continuity
column6: To provide business continuity, security and Information Assurance (IA) policies, strategies and services to the Department, and to ensure that there are effective continuity plans for all major risks to the business.  I am also the Departmental Security Officer (DSO), a mandated Cabinet Office role.

column6:
To develop and ensure delivery of the Finance & Commercial Group business plan to ensure its objectives are delivered to time, cost and quality.
The role includes owning the target operating model for the Group; helping build financial and commercial capability internally and across DWP; and delivering continuous improvement, administrative support and communications services.

To deliver procurement and commercial law services to DWP and Department for Health.

column5: Director, Professional Services Group, DWP/ Department of Health Legal Services
column6: To provide a legal service to the Department of Health in the areas of commercial law, employment law and litigation.
The team provides  legal services in relation to all existing working age benefits: Jobseekers Allowance, Employment and Support Allowance, Incapacity Benefit and Income Support, Universal Credit .

column6: Our role is to respond professionally to feedback (correspondence, complaints, appeals) about the Department’s services; to give guidance to the Department’s front-line decision-makers; and to promote appropriate regulation and effective management of legislation.
Communications handling, advice and provision of marketing for the Department.

column6: Communications handling, advice and provision of marketing for the Department.

column5: Deputy Director of Communications - Labour Market Operations
column6: Delivering strategic communications & marketing for the Government's employment programmes including Youth Contract & Work Programme. Leading team delivering a range of communications into DWP Operations & acting as communications business partner to the Operational Executive Team.

column5: Head of Internal Communications and the Studio
column6: Internal communications and the Studio exists to help staff and citizens understand DWP better, whether that is the services the Department offers or the part they play in making DWP’s objectives to reform welfare and pensions a success. The team achieves this through communications advice, planning, channel delivery (including the DWP website and intranet, DirectGov and Businesslink websites) and brand management. The team has a duty to fulfil the Department’s legal requirements to provide information to citizens which includes corporate publications (such as green papers), leaflets, letters, forms and display materials for Jobcentre Plus and Pension Disability and Carers Service.

column5: Deputy Director of Communications Universal Credit

Overall leadership of the Department, and its day to day operations and the Government's programme of major reform.

The Commissioner is appointed by the Secretary of State for Work and Pensions. This is a statutory appointment, with duties provided by Acts of Parliament and is required to report annually, in writing, to the Secretary of State on the standard of reviews by Social Fund Inspectors.

These teams enable the Department to meet its statutory duty to provide 'duty of care' information on benefits and services to claimants and the wider public, support the Government's digital agenda working with GDS to provide user-focussed online and digital information and campaigns, and ensure that Communications Directorate activity is effective through use of insight and performance measurement.

Responsible for delivering proactive communications activity relating to private pensions, state pensions, pensioners (pensioner benefits and ageing society) and working longer. The team works in partnership with a wide range of stakeholders and with other government bodies, in particular, The Pensions Regulator and HMRC and plans and implements a range of communications to inform people about pensions policy changes, to help people (individuals and employers) understand what the changes are, what they mean for them and any action they must take.

To provide advice on handling media for the department and for Ministers. To answer questions from journalists about the work of the department. To handle the media element of announcements, speeches and visits by the Ministerial team and Permanent Secretary.

Introduction and leadership of the case closure operational process.  Responsibility for the G4S Options contract which provides a service to people who need help and support to arrange child maintenance.  Leadership of People issues within Child Maintenance Operations

- activity to improve people engagement 
- design, development, maintenance and evaluation of all business specific training

Leading all financial matters within CMG including financial management, reporting, accounting and business performance reporting and ensuring that value for money is delivered. Responsible for leading the Commission’s commercial and supplier relationship activities and contributing to the future direction of the organisation by offering advice to the Executive Team and Ministers, and delivering CMG’s planning, analysis, management information and research activities.

The IT Services team provides operational service management for the Child Maintenance Group's current applications and infrastructure. The team is responsible for incident, problem, availability, change request and service level management. Working with our IT suppliers, it ensures that our systems meet business needs in a cost effective manner. The team also provides IT services to support desktop PCs, telephones and networks. It also provides security accreditation and assurance services.

The purpose of the Strategy team is to develop a coherent high-level strategy for the Child Maintenance Group, setting out how its three key functions will be developed to realise the Child Maintenance Group's vision and meet its statutory objectives. The work of the team covers: - strategic advice to senior stakeholders; - development of policy on the new statutory scheme using income data from HM Revenue and Customs; - developing strategy for promoting financial responsibility and the longer term development of the information and support function including - cross-government opportunities; - strategic input to the corporate planning process.

The Client Services Director is responsible for:
- Assessing and making payment arrangements for new and repeat child maintenance applications. 
- Updating child maintenance cases by processing changes of circumstances to ensure that the correct amount of child maintenance is paid. 
- The provision of telephony, face to face visiting and Welsh language services. 
- Responding to complaints received from clients or MPs, ensuring that the reason for the complaint is addressed and appropriate action taken to resolve the issues.

The Operations Director is responsible for providing direction to the operation of the current statutory schemes and for the delivery of performance indicators and service standards.  This means delivering improved client service whilst continuing to achieve efficiencies.  Responsible for influencing the design, development and content of the new statutory scheme programmes to ensure they are fit for purpose and deliver planned efficiencies and operational management of the new scheme following its introduction.

The Policy division is made up of three teams: Policy Team – Ensuring the law governing child support is fit for purpose and the Child Maintenance Group's policies and procedures, and handling of individual cases are in line with the law and reflect the Government's strategic intent; Advice and Guidance Team - Providing support to frontline colleagues to ensure that child support cases are handled in line with Child Maintenance policies and procedures; Judicial Review Team – Ensuring those cases on which we face escalated legal action are managed in line with legal advice and court requirements.
This team are responsible for the delivery of elements of the new child maintenance scheme. This includes the organisation design, site strategy and any third party contracts.

The Performance and Resources Director is responsible for a range of geographically dispersed operational planning activities primarily focused on supporting performance and service delivery, and co-ordinating effective business improvement.  This includes; financial planning and budgetary control; resource planning; performance planning and management; and area services management.

column5: Head of Business Architecture and Design
column6: The Business Architecture and Design Team design and develop business processes and procedures.

The Legal Team provides a wide ranging legal advice service to the Child Maintenance Group, covering commercial contracts/procurement exercises (including business process outsourcing and specialist services), employment law/transfers of undertakings, privacy law, freedom of information, civil enforcement and public law. The Head of Legal is the Legal Advisor to the Child Maintenance Group and is responsible for Board Governance. The Team also incorporates a criminal prosecutions function which brings prosecutions for fraud, theft and other offences under Child Support Legislation.

The Programme Delivery Director is responsible for driving delivery of the Child Maintenance change programme, with lead responsibilities including delivery assurance; project planning and interdependencies; programme assurance and reporting; risks and issues management; and programme resource planning.  The Director also has responsibility for People and Capability programme deliverables, including organisation design; workforce planning and people allocation; content product delivery and live like testing; business preparation; and implementation control.  The Director also acts as deputy for the CMG Change Director.

The Information and Technology Directorate is responsible for ensuring that the Child Maintenance Group current and future Information Technology and Information Management needs are met. The Directorate provides local IT support, telephony services, and operational support for the Child Maintenance Group's current business applications. The Directorate is also supporting the Child Maintenance Group's change programme, building with third parties a range of applications for the new child maintenance scheme. In addition, the directorate provides information assurance and IT security services to protect information and systems within the Child Maintenance Group.

column5: Head of Information Governance and Security
column6:
The Information Governance and Security team is responsible for information assurance, IT security, knowledge management and management information systems for the Child Maintenance Group. The team: 
- defines the approach to the protection of information (including that of clients) for the Child Maintenance Group,
- providing assurance of information risks,
- design processes and systems to ensure the Child Maintenance Group's systems and infrastructure are protected, 
- design, develop and deliver solutions to manage unstructured data, 
- develop and deliver a 'data warehouse', business intelligence and other management information systems and
- maintain the Child Maintenance Group's data model.
This team are responsible for the delivery of elements of the new child maintenance scheme. This includes the organisation design, site strategy and any third party contracts.
Responsible for the day to day running of Child Maintenance Group & its operations, change, corporate affairs and customer functions.

The  Enforcement Director is responsible for re-establishing compliance on the current and new child maintenance schemes through debt enforcement actions: negotiation and imposing deduction from earning orders where required.  On cases where debt enforcement action has failed, responsible for re-establishing compliance using measures including charging orders, third party debt orders, obtaining Liability Orders for debt through the Courts, driving licence removal and even the possibility of imprisonment.

column5: Clerical and Client Payment Services Director
column6:
The Clerical and Client Payment Services Director is responsible for: 
• Processing receipts and payments as quickly as possible, through the collection service. 
• Improving performance on cases managed off the Child Maintenance Group's main IT systems. 
• Reducing the number of cases managed off the main IT systems - don't understand this, how can we do this?
• Improving the efficiency of managing cases off the main IT systems

column5: Senior Finance and Commercial Business Partner for DWP Child Maintenance Group (CMG)
column6: As a key member of the DWP Operational Finance senior leadership team, the Senior Finance and Commercial Business Partner for Child Maintenance Group will provide professional, evidence based, decision making support, challenge and professional advice to the Directors on all aspects of financial management, performance, value for money, commercial investment, procurement advice and risk.  This will be achieved by taking a leading and co-ordinating role across a range of business disciplines (i.e. Financial Management and Control, Performance Management, Commercial Management, Risk Management and oversight of Assurance). The role is unique in that it also covers the transactional flows, financial control within systems and accounting for the flow of monies from one parent to another, commonly known as Accounting for Client Funds.

The Child Maintenance Options service provides free, impartial information on child maintenance arrangements, and supports parents to make informed decisions about the child maintenance arrangement most suited to their circumstances, whether this is a family-based or statutory arrangement or one made through the courts. 

Child Maintenance Options is available by phone, web or, for those most in need of more personalised help, through a face-to-face service. The Child Maintenance Options team in the Child Maintenance Group manages all aspects of the service from performance to service development.
The Change Directorate leads the implementation of major change projects, ensuring that projects are delivered to time and to budget.
